content.text: Calculate the density, in \(\text{g} \text{cm}^{- 3}\), of the metal
density =   .........  \(\text{g} \text{cm}^{- 3}\)
Determine the percentage uncertainty in the density
percentage uncertainty =   .........  %
A solid metal sphere has a diameter of \((3.42 \pm 0.02) \text{cm}\) and a mass of \((67 \pm 2) \text{g}\)
Show that the time taken for the arrow to reach the target is 1.08 s
Calculate the height of the centre of the target above the ground
height above ground =   .........  m

By considering energy changes, state and explain how the final kinetic energy of the arrow as it hits the target compares with its initial kinetic energy immediately after release. A numerical calculation is not required
An archer releases an arrow towards a target at a velocity of \(65.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(4.30^{\circ}\) above the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 2.1
When released, the tip of the arrow is a horizontal distance of \(70.0 \text{m}\) from the target and \(1.66 \text{m}\) above the horizontal ground
The arrow hits the centre of the target
Assume that air resistance is negligible and that all the mass of the arrow is at its tip
Define velocity
Calculate the acceleration of the car
acceleration =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-2}\)
On Fig. 3.1, sketch a graph showing the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the car for the first 20 seconds of its motion
Label this line A
A constant driving force of \(2400\mathrm{N}\) acts on a car of mass \(1200\mathrm{kg}\). The car accelerates from rest in a straight line along a horizontal road
Assume that the resistive forces acting on the car are negligible
On Fig. 3.1, sketch a second line to show the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the car for the first 20 seconds of its motion. Label this line B
At time \(t = 20 \text{s}\), the driving force is increased to \(3000 \text{N}\) and remains constant at this value
Describe how the velocity of the car changes due to this increase in the driving force

In reality, a resistive force due to air resistance acts on the car in **(b)**. This resistive force increases with speed until it becomes equal in magnitude to the driving force at time \(t = 12 \text{s}\)
A mass \(m\) moves a vertical distance \(\Delta h\) in a uniform gravitational field and gains gravitational potential energy \(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}}\). The acceleration of free fall is \(g\)
Use the concept of work done to show that
A \(0.60\mathrm{kg}\) mass is attached to a string which is wrapped around the wheel of a generator, as shown in Fig. 4.1

The mass is held stationary above the floor. When released, the mass initially accelerates and then falls at a steady speed and spins the wheel. The generator causes a current in a resistor. Air resistance is negligible
State the main energy change when the mass is falling at a steady speed
the rate of work done by the falling mass
rate of work done =   .........  W
the power dissipated in the resistor
the efficiency of the generator
efficiency =   .........

When falling at a steady speed, the mass in **(b)** falls through a vertical distance of \(1.4 \text{m}\) in a time of \(4.0 \text{s}\). This causes a current of \(90 \text{mA}\) in the resistor. The resistance of the resistor is \(47 \Omega\)
Calculate:
The magnifying glass is circular in cross-section with a radius of \(5.5 \text{cm}\). The intensity of the light from the Sun incident on the magnifying glass is \(1.3 \text{kW} \text{m}^{-2}\)
Assume that all of the light incident on the magnifying glass is transmitted through it
Calculate the power of the light from the Sun incident on the magnifying glass
The value of \(r\) is \(1.5 \text{mm}\)
Calculate the intensity of the light on area A
intensity =   .........  \(\text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\)
Parallel light rays from the Sun are incident normally on a magnifying glass. The magnifying glass directs the light to an area A of radius \(r\), as shown in Fig. 5.1
parallel light rays from Sun
Show that the wavelength of the waves is \(8.1 \times 10^{- 8} \text{m}\)
State the region of the electromagnetic spectrum to which these waves belong

The beam from the laser now passes through a diffraction grating with 2400 lines per millimetre. A detector sensitive to the waves emitted by the laser is moved through an arc of \(180^{\circ}\) in order to detect the maxima produced by the waves passing through the grating, as shown in Fig. 5.2
The laser is now replaced with one that emits electromagnetic waves with a wavelength of \(300 \text{nm}\)
Explain, without calculation, what happens to the number of maxima now detected. Assume that the detector is also sensitive to this wavelength of electromagnetic waves
A laser emits a beam of electromagnetic waves of frequency \(3.7 \times 10^{15} \text{Hz}\) in a vacuum
On Fig. 6.1, sketch the \(I - V\) characteristic of a filament lamp
Explain the shape of the line in (a)(i)
A conducting wire has length \(5.8 \text{m}\) and cross-sectional area \(3.4 \times 10^{- 8} \text{m}^2\). The resistivity of the metal of the wire is \(5.6 \times 10^{- 8} \Omega \text{m}\)
Calculate the resistance of the wire
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)

A resistor of resistance \(R\) is placed in a circuit with a cell of negligible internal resistance, two switches \(\mathsf{S}_1\) and \(\mathsf{S}_2\), a second resistor of resistance \(2R\) and three ammeters X, Y and Z. The circuit is shown in Fig. 6.2
The reading on X is 1.0A when \(\mathsf{S}_1\) is open and \(\mathsf{S}_2\) is closed
Complete Table 6.1

table.html:
position of switchesammeter readings
\(S_{1}\)\(S_{2}\)reading on X/Areading on Y/Areading on Z/A
openopen000
openclosed1.0
closedopen
closedclosed

content.text: Complete the nuclear equation for the decay, including all the particles involved
A quark in the fluorine-18 nucleus changes flavour during the decay. State this change of flavour
Fluorine-18 ( \(^{18}_{8}\mathrm{F})\) is an isotope that decays to an isotope of oxygen (O) by the emission of a \(\beta^{+}\) particle
State and explain whether the hadron is a meson or a baryon
State a possible quark composition for the hadron
A hadron has a charge of \(-2e\), where \(e\) is the elementary charge
